newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: Ireland's CBT in 5.7 mln punt expansion.
newsitem.headline: Ireland's CBT in 5.7 mln punt expansion.

text.p: Irish software company CBT Group Plc, which is listed on the NASDAQ market in New York, announced plans on Monday to increase its Irish workforce by 200 in a 5.7 million punt expansion.

"CBT is growing rapidly and our intention is to accelerate that rate of expansion as our market continues to grow," CBT chief executive Bill Mc Cabe said at the opening of the company's Worldwide Development Centre in Dublin.
CBT, which already employs 120 in Dublin, produces interactive education training software used in the information technology sector to train staff.
Since CBT's flotation on the NASDAQ market in 1995, McCabe said the market value of the company had increased from $230 million to $950 million.

Total employment in the Dublin office will rise to 320 by 1998 compared with 80 less than 12 months ago. CBT also employs 237 people worldwide and it expects this number to grow to 315 by early 1998, bringing total worldwide employment to 635.

Irish Enterprise and Employment Minister Richard Bruton said CBT's expansion demonstrated Ireland's "increasingly competitive position" in securing investment from firms in the computer services sector.

CBT also published results on Monday, showing a rise of 113 percent in third quarter net income to $3.4 million or $0.17 per equivalent American Depositary Share while revenues increased by 62 percent in the period to $17.0 million.
"Our third quarter financial results reflect our continued progress in expanding our product offerings, growing our customer base and enhancing our management team," McCabe said.
He said CBT had introduced 44 new titles to the marketplace during the third quarter and had a total of 279 titles at September 30.
